original_title: Sri Lanka power commission chief says willing to enter politics to empower citizens
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Outspoken Chairman of Sri Lanka’s Public Utilities Commission Janaka Ratnayake says he is ready to enter politics under certain conditions, provided and opportunity is given.

“If I am given an opportunity to bring forward a good proposal where every citizen is empowered, embraced, encouraged, and entrusted to make this a better place, I’m always open to do that,” Ratnayake told EconomyNext.
Members of the public is seeking a “good administration, unbiased individuals who can deliver”, he said.
“Certain families and elite politicians have been playing for 75 years,” Ratnayake said.
“So, to make that change by the request of everyone, I think I am open for it.”

In 2022 Sri Lanka ran into the worst currency crisis since the creation of the central bank after economists printed money to suppress rates and target an output gap also known as monetary stimulus adding fiscal stimulus (tax cuts) to the mix.
Ratnayake has come under fire for resisting a hike in power tariffs to reduce domestic credit, after the rupee collapsed.
Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera has criticized Ratnayake. There have been calls to remove him from the independent commission.
Ratnayake was appointed during the time of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa. Wijesekera was also elected from ex-President Rajapaksa’s part.

“I never had any personal issues with the minister,” Ratnayake said.  “We had a very cordial relationship and during the presidential and general elections, he was the coordinator between me and the parties and the president, so we knew each other very well.
“This is an independent commission, and I do my job.” (Colombo/Apr15/2023)
